channel.title: Visual Basic - Im looking to make a TCP sever
channel.description:
hey guys,
Im looking into making a sort of server in visual basic using TCP conenctions. It will be associated with scar and i want it to function somewhat like this -
[b]Scar Sends data to the server
Data is processed and saved to a .ini file
This file then can be downloaded from the server in the .ini extension[/b]
I know this is a little breif but my experience in VB streches little further than making a client for rs2 following a tutorial. I was wondering if any experienced VB programmers could confirm that this can/should work and also if possible help me acheive it.
Be great to hear what you guys have to say
Solemn Wishes.

item.title: Visual Basic - Im looking to make a TCP sever
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:6, topic:245368”][quote author=Niall link=topic=321802.msg2549888#msg2549888 date=1227458011]

You’re making a keylogger, aren’t you?

In SCAR?
[/quote]

It’s possible, but you’ll have to be really stupid if you’ll actually fall for it. I believe that Kane made one about a year ago.[/quote]

Ron did too, it is just a simply horrible way to make a keylogger, regardless if they [quote=“Unhandled, post:7, topic:245368”]record the username and password used to log in to rs, then send them to the server[/quote] or not.

Sure, it may work if you obfuscate the script but then the only way to send/receive network data in SCAR without a dialog window asking you if you allow the connection would be through a plugin.

Read full topic
item.source: Visual Basic - Im looking to make a TCP sever

In SCAR?[/quote]

item.title: Visual Basic - Im looking to make a TCP sever
item.dc:creator: @eVokki1 Cowie`
item.description:
@eVokki1 wrote:

I know you probably won’t care but why use Visual Basic for this - , when you can use a simple python script and just modify it.

import socket
from threading import *
sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)

sock.bind(('127.0.0.1', 8124))
sock.listen(5)

def apeer(client, peer):
    while 1:
        data = client.recv(500)
        if not data: break
        else:
            print data
            f = open('lolz.ini', 'a')
            f.write(str(data) + '\n')
            f.close()

print 'Started listening'
while 1:
    client, peer = sock.accept()
    cpeer = str(peer[0]) + ':' + str(peer[1])
    print 'New peer', cpeer
    threading.start_new_thread(apeer, (client, peer))

Read full topic
